utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: I was uh, wondering what I could help you with today?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah hi, um, I have been coughing nonstop for the past three days, and today I have been feeling very short of breath. So I just wanted to get it all checked out.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Yeah, for sure. And, so you said the cough started uh, three days ago. Were there any triggers to the cough or anything that, uh that changed three days ago?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, nothing that I can think of um, I have, like the only thing that I've been doing is going to the grocery stores, uh the bank, and laundromat. Um, and once I ran all these errands, like, I just started having this coughing fit that hasn't stopped.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, uh, has the cough gotten any better, or stayed the same, or gotten worse these past three days?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh, it seems like it's getting worse.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, are you bringing up any uh, sputum or phlegm?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um yes, it's yellow.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, is this um, any different from before? Like have you had a cough in the past and, and brought up phlegm, or is this entirely new for you?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um no, this has happened to me before, um, like I don't know, like maybe a year or two years back. Uh, and it kind of feels the same, but just a little bit worse.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay. Um, and uh, have you seen any blood in the sputum?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, no blood.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay. Um, and you mentioned you've been short of breath as well. Uh, how has that come on?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um, it was, I, I don't know if it's because of all the coughing that I've been doing, but it just started this morning.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, um, and have you been experiencing uh shortness of breath um, on exertion otherwise, like prior to this?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um no, no.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay. And have you had any shortness of breath after, like if you lie down flat?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um, no, not that I've noticed

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: All right, and have you had a wheeze?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: A little bit, yeah.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay um, uh, and have you had any um, infectious-like symptoms such as like red eyes, runny nose, or, or a sore throat?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, nothing like that.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, um, have you had any, any chest pain?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Nope, nothing like that.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Have you had any lightheadedness or, or feeling dizzy?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Or feeling like your heart's racing or, or beating really fast?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay. And, um, have you had any fevers or chills?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, not that I've noticed.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Have you had any night sweats?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: And how has your weight been over the last several months? Have you had any weight loss or gain?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh no, it's been pretty stable.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay. Um, and have you had any abdominal pain?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um, no.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Any diarrhea?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Or any urinary problems?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay. Um, and in the past um, oh sorry, before that, have you had any nausea or, or vomiting?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay. Uh, and any confusion or, or changes to um, um memory?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, uh, or loss of taste or sense of smell?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh no.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay uh, so the, you've been experiencing this cough that's been getting worse over the last couple of days, as well as bringing up some yellow sputum, um, and been short of breath. Have you been experiencing any other symptoms?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, that's pretty much it.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay. Um, and in the past, have you um, been diagnosed with any medical conditions?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um, I have diabetes, I have high blood pressure and I have high cholesterol.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: I see. Alright, and do you take uh, medications for those things?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yes, so I am on ramipril for the high blood pressure, rosuvastatin for the cholesterol, and insulin for the diabetes.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, thank you. And uh, you mentioned you had a similar episode in the past. Um, what, uh, were you diagnosed with COPD before?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I was, I was diagnosed with COPD about five years back.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, did you have pulmonary function tests for this? The test where you had to breathe into a tube.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um yeah, I had that done like five years ago.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, um, alright um, just wanted to see if it was uh like formally diagnosed. Sometimes people uh, um, yeah, it's important to have that, uh, those tests done. Um, and do you have any allergies?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um, no none. None, yeah.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay. Um, and uh, are your immunizations up to date?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yes, I believe so.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, um and have you had any surgeries or, or um, hospitalizations?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um, I had my Gallbladder removed when I was in my 50s. Um, and I had a hip fracture three years ago.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, and how is your mobility now?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um pretty good. My hips still give me some issues once in awhile, but um, for the most part, it's been okay.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, that's good. It sounds like the rehab went well.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: And uh, right now, can you tell me um, a little bit about your living situation? Like where you're living and who you're living with?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um, I live by myself in an apartment on the 1st floor.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, um and, do you smoke cigarettes?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh no, I quit two years ago.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, and that's, that's great. Um, prior to that, how long did you smoke for, and how much?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Oh, for like 40-plus years um, I used to smoke a pack a day.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, well that's great that uh, that you quit, so congratulations.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: And do you drink alcohol?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I drink once in a while. Like maybe every other day, I'll have a glass of wine.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, and um, uh anybody, or sorry, have you been around anybody who's been sick recently?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh no.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: You said you went to the stores and stuff like that.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, maybe from there, yeah.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, and have you traveled anywhere else, outside of the city?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um, not recently, no.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Alright, um, and any exposures to any like dust, chemicals, things like that?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um, I live in an old building so maybe. Um, but it hasn't bugged me before.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, uh, and are you working currently or, or retired?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I'm retired.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, well, what did you do before?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I used to work uh, on the assembly line for Chrysler.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, were there any exposures uh, there that you were aware of, like things that you were breathing in?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh not that I was aware of, but they were always like smoke and fumes and things like that because it was like a factory, so maybe.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Right, okay, that makes sense. Um, and in the family, are there, anybody who, who's had problems with their hearts or lungs?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um, my mom had lung cancer when she was 50. And, like, all the, like diabetes, hypertension and high cholesterol runs on my, ran on my father's side of the family.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: I see, did anybody have uh, heart attacks or, or stroke?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh, yeah, so my father had a heart attack when he was 49. Uh, stroke I'm not too sure about.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, thank you. And, um, so that was all I wanted to ask about. Um, was there anything else that you wanted to add that I maybe forgot?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um, no, that's about it, but I, how can I treat myself now? How do I make this cough go away?

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: For sure, so, um, we will first get your vitals here and we'll see if your oxygen levels um, are low, then it would be important to put on some oxygen first, um, just to make sure that that's stable. Um, and from there we will um, get a chest x-ray um, and uh, run some lab work to, to try to help figure out the, the diagnosis better, but in the meantime, we'll use um, some inhalers because it's possible that this is a COPD exacerbation similar to uh last year, um, and the inhalers should help open up the airways and dilate, so make breathing easier, and then um, also if it is a COPD exacerbation, it will likely require antibiotics, as well as some steroids for the, the inflammation for five days. Uh, but since your symptoms currently overlap with uh, COVID as well, you'll have to get a, a COVID nasal swab.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Okay, okay for sure.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Okay, so uh, we'll get that started.

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Add differential diagnosis
